headline.main: Key Senator Says He Will Alter Health Proposal

docs.snippet: Senator Max Baucus, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said that he would modify his health care bill to provide more assistance to middle-income Americans, to help them buy insurance.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Senate Finance Committee takes up its health care bill on Tuesday, advocates who favor a public option are planning to stage demonstrations nationwide against the health insurance industry. Supporters of a public option, or a government-run insurance plan, see it as the central component of a true health care overhaul. But the insurance industry strenuously opposes the idea, and it was not part of the proposal introduced last week by the Finance Committee chairman, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.
docs.abstract: Advocates who favor public option plan to stage demonstrations nationwide against health insurance industry when Senate Finance Committee takes up health care bill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An entry in the Prescriptions column on Aug. 22 about an appearance on the ''Daily Show'' by the former New York lieutenant governor Betsy McCaughey misstated her political affiliation. Ms. McCaughey has been a registered Democrat since September 1997; she is not a Republican. (Before 1997, she did not declare a political preference when she registered to vote.)
docs.abstract: Correction of August 22 Prescriptions column about appearance on television program Daily Show by former Republican New York Lieutenant Gov Betsy McCaughey, who has been registered Democrat since September 1997; she discussed possible reform of health care system (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before the voting comes the speech making. As the Senate Finance Committee takes up the big health care bill on Tuesday, the first order of business will be opening statements. Given the intense national interest, all 23 committee members are expected to make full-throated use of their allotted five minutes -- or longer in the case of the chairman, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and the senior Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa.
docs.abstract: All 23 members are expected to make opening statements, likely to be more political theater than policy, as Senate Finance Committee takes up health care bill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps nothing in medicine more aptly depicts the paradoxical statement ''doing better, feeling worse'' than high blood pressure. Despite an extraordinarily easy way to detect it, strong evidence for how to prevent it and proven remedies to treat it, more Americans today have undetected or poorly controlled hypertension than ever before. The aging of the population is a reason but not the only one, said Dr. Aram V. Chobanian, a hypertension expert at Boston University Medical Center. As he summarized the problem in an interview and in The New England Journal of Medicine in August, Americans are too sedentary and fat. They eat too much, especially salt, but too few potassium-rich fruits and vegetables.

headline.main: Too Much Salt Takes a Blood-Pressure Toll
